I've confined no evidence whatever Your Honor that the courts have disregarded an information filed by a prosecuting attorney, asserting the application of the recidivist statute would be an unbelievable thing.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does the -- well perhaps the Attorney General should laid on this --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. -- Mr. Ginsburg before you sit down, I have two questions, first of all on this matter to which you've just been addressing yourself.

If the statute instead of being in terms mandatory said that the prosecuting attorney may apply to this, that then you would have in statutory term which told us that the -- that isn't in fact the practice of West Virginia.
And it's also the language of the statute in the case of the Warden.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, now aren't there -- aren't there many States where the statute is permissive?
Many States whereas permissive.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's more -- more usual, isn't it?
Much more usual.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And so therefore, this practice is simple in conforming in practice to what the statutes of the other States say, is that it?
In disregard of the -- of the terms of the statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So we're faced here if you're right as to this practice where we have then just --
An equal protection probably now.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We have -- we have the equivalent of -- of a statute of which says by this constitutional question goes we have an equivalent of the statute which says the prosecutor may instead of must.
Isn't that correct to the constitutional point of view?
Well, here is the man -- is this not the problem before the Court in ever case where an equal protection is asserted to be denied?
Here a criminal in jail, 79 out of 983. 904 have gone free so far as concerns the statute.
The 79 have been put away on what basis, who was making the law?
This -- these prosecuting attorneys are making the law in the State of West Virginia.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: There are so many factors though.
They may not have known of the prior convictions.
Well, there are --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Inaudible)
-- the date is set forth in the record sir and I will arrest on that.
It's very clear that they did know, they do know and it's very clear that this is a problem to --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But West Virginia said about it, I mean the Supreme Court?

Well, this problem has not been -- the problem of equal protection was asserted, was allege was contained in the habeas corpus application which was submitted to the Supreme Court, but there was no opinion.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm wondering myself Mr. Ginsburg on your earlier point if I may?
Yes sir.
I --well, just one word that it's not -- I'm not asserting here that these men will go free that is at either due process has been denied here, procedural due process or equal protection.
What well happen then is that these men will be resentenced by the trial court for the original crimes, in the one case for second degree murder and the other case for the crime of forgery.
It's not that they will go free.
The problem is the enhanced punishment by reason of the application of the recidivist statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I want to be sure Mr. Ginsburg before you sit down that I understand what it is that these people now assert they could have brought before the sentencing court?
Well, in the case of Oyler.
Oyler said that I should have been permitted to tell the trial court that I was never in the penitentiary before.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, isn't that problem, not ambiguity between 18 and 19 completely resolved by this Skeen case or the Keen case or whatever it is?
Well, I'm not sure whether it is, because in that case -- you see, there is a distinction in my mind of court between a jail and the -- and a reformatory.
And the one came that under the law of West Virginia reformatory is not even the penal institution even tough confinement is involuntary.
The cases are collected in the brief and I should think that the matter of this kind would be argued before the Court.
That -- I can concede.
You see in the Johnson case that a jail penitentiary -- a county jail is contest over the States penitentiary could be assimilated.
But to assimilate a -- is there -- when a man, let's say right -- child is sent to a -- young man sent a reformatory school, does that to be simulated to the penitentiary?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, we -- but in -- in the Keen case, if I have the name right, Keen isn't or Skeen?
John --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Skeen case.
Well, Skeen --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That was (Voice Overlap) Skeen.
-- the Warden at that time.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It wasn't on that basis of the -- that the West Virginia Court decided it. It was on the basis that 18 was controlling overnight.

I agree and I -- I said at the time that during my argument, I believe that was a wrong result, but I believe -- and I believe they should have argued before them the -- this issue, that issue or issues of this kind.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now is that sole issue that -- that Oyler says he would -- could have brought before the Court?
No.
Oyler of course raises the problem of a -- I mean under the statute?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
That is the issue which Oyler presently asserts he could have raised under the statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And how about Crabtree?
Crabtree points to errors in the information.
The error between -- Yakima and Walla Walla.
And -- but both raise -- the men raised of course what I believe to be these great constitutional questions.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I was wondering --
Certainly procedure in due process --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- understanding to raise those if they not so that they were prejudiced here.
Yes.

Well I've -- it's not conceivable to me that they would -- could not raise as a federal matter in a petition for habeas corpus alleging the invalidity of the statute, because the statute denies them the opportunity -- the ample notice and an opportunity for a hearing on these issues.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I can -- I can see how the Walla Walla -- the difference in the counties act there in identification.
Could conceivably.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The party (Inaudible) --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- but if the custom identification is now pertinent what (Inaudible) could it have apart from -- I always concede that your statutory point be different from once you talked a lot of (Inaudible)
Your suggestion sir, bear on the issue of harmless error, that there maybe error in the record by it's harmless.
My point is that they should have had an opportunity to argue to the Court what the merits of those issues were.
And it's the lack of opportunity to reach the Court, to discuss the matter with the Court that I'm complaining about here and I believe that that's the essential issue in the case.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Ginsburg, we've taken much of your time asking questions.
You may have five minutes more to wish to respond and of course, Mr. Mitchell may have -- you have (Inaudible) time.
Thank you sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Mitchell, you may now proceed with your argument.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
The counsels for petitioners have stated the fact substantially.

Petitioner Oyler was indicted for murder by the grand juries of the Circuit Court of Taylor County West Virginia at it's Jan -- January 1953 term, he was arraigned and as his request court-appointed counsel to assist him in his the defense.
He then entered the plea of not guilty and his case was sent for trial.
The trial was held and the jury found him guilty of murder in the second degree.
At that time, it's pointed out counsel for the petitioner.
The petitioner here moved the Court to set aside the verdict and grant new trial, the Court during that time for counsel to assign his ground in support of the motion.

Approximately one week later after the verdict of the jury was received, the Court overruled the motion for a new trial and at that time, (Inaudible) the prosecuting attorney then counted that information, set and forth in writ -- this information was in writ, they filed a writ, set and forth three previews felony convictions of petition -- petitioner Oyler in the Court for (Inaudible) session of the piece in the county of Bedford, in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, on the charge of (Inaudible) larceny of automobile, breaking and entering burglary.

The order of commitment in connection with petitioner Oyler states that after being duly cautioned as to the effect thereof, he acknowledged in open court that he was the same person named in the information.
And thereupon, the Court proceeded on the -- on the habitual criminal statute to sentence the petitioner Oyler to confinement in the -- in the penitentiary of the State for life.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Mitchell may I -- may I ask you at this time if there is any defense open to the defendant on habitual criminal charge other than that of identity?
Under our statute -- the -- the prisoner given opportunity, he is duly caution as to the effect of saying that he is the same person.
And the --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's the question of identity.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.
And -- if he says that he is not the same person, a jury must be empanelled to try the question of identity to determine whether or not he is the same person.
And if he acknowledges after being duly cautioned, the court sentences him.
Now is practice then a question has been raised and continue to say have been granted.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I beg pardon?
Continue to say have been granted it so that this question can be determined.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What question of identity?
Identity.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, suppose a man -- suppose the man says, “Yes”.

I am the person referred to in this information, but I was pardoned by the Governor of Pennsylvania because he found I was innocent and my -- my other conviction was voided by the courts because they found that it was -- I was unconstitutionally convicted, but I -- but I am the person was who mentioned in that information,” can he raise those questions?
He can raise those questions.
If he didn't -- well, let's go back, if he denied that he is entitled to a jury trial and the State must then put on evidence.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no, that isn't what I'm talking about.
He admits that he is the person referred to in those -- in the information.

Does that end his defense or does he have other defenses such as he had received a full pardon from the Government because of his -- because of his innocence or he had had his other conviction reversed because he was unconstitutionally convicted?
Can he raise those -- those issues if he admits his identity?
Yes, he could raise those issues.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.
Now, what law of your state gives it?
Is there a statute concerning that or is that interpretation of your Supreme Court?
Then -- the Court has -- not rules specifically on that.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.
And we have observed it in practice.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You what -- you what?
It had been observed in practice that you can raise any question that has to do with whether or not the conviction is proper one to sustain the application of the habitual criminal law.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, under what statute do you do that?
We have no specific statute on that sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And how -- how frequently has that been done in practice --
(Voice Overlap) very infrequently.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I beg pardon?
Infrequently.
It's not been frequent.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you then in your knowledge have in mind any cases where it's done?

I have observed several in the -- in immediate court into North County where it has been raised and if -- the prisoner was permitted to show this discrepancy or whatever merit was that would show that he -- the conviction that was being set forth was not a proper one or application under habitual criminal statute.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Are there -- are those opinions reported?
No sir, they're not reported.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: There are no opinions reported opinions (Voice Overlap) --
On that question, no sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You use to answer Mr. Chief Justice that it -- as a matter of practice, he's allowed to interpose considerations other than lack of (Inaudible) and mis-identity.
I think you said --
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- practice.
But I want to know you've also said there is no decision dealing with it.
Is there any reference in any -- in any opinion, either by the lower court or by your Supreme Court?
Is there any statement in Crabtree which reflects that practice?
Is there any statement?
I don't mean an adjudication but very often, judges in writing, state as the matter of fact, reference so to the fact under this State.
Do you recall any such reference shorter than actual adjudication?
No Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I do not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now what I looked at the briefs as -- has talked to Mr. Ginsburg in the Graham case and the Graham -- Graham was -- the case was argued here, on the brief there is -- one of the (Inaudible) lawyers of this day Mr. Frank Holden and he takes it for granted.

I'm not suggesting that that's controlling law but (Inaudible) shed some light in this groping darkness and in that brief that it said, “The only defense opened in West Virginia is identical,” the issue of identification.
As I say that -- that goes no more than accounts a statement.
It is interesting to me that none of these questions was raised in that case.
Maybe there's no basis for raising any.
The Graham case went entirely in challenging the method for determining identity namely, by way of information against in your State, you have to have an indictment (Inaudible) felony.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I'm just groping to see whether there's anything in any legal, in any weighty pronouncement by any judge that as a matter of practice, Mr. Hogan was wrong in saying the only defense is to establish identification.
Not and think of no -- not in publish to that effect.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But you speak out of you own experience.
Yes sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You've been -- you've been in the Justice Department of the State of West Virginia, how long Mr. Mitchell?
This is my fifth year.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your fifth year.
Yes, sir, I was in practice --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Voice Overlap) you presented criminal cases?
Mostly, always.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Pardon me.
It just went on and my record has been in a craft.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And the -- and the records come over or the proceedings come over your desk (Inaudible)
That's true sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But Mr. Mitchell, the one of professors of law school made to rather extensive study of this subject, did he not?
That's true.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did he --
Mr. Bryant.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- did he comment on -- on this precise question that Justice Frankfurter now you're discussing that?
No, he did not.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: He didn't go in to that?
No sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.
It's been pointed out, petitioner Crabtree was indicted by the grand jury of Lincoln County West Virginia for the offense of forging a $35 check.
He was arraigned and entered a plea of guilty and then one -- perhaps in one week later, the prosecuting attorney filed an information --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We will recess now Mr. Mitchell.
